or, compile the source yourself
I did that - but right now I have to run a terminal, do "cd pogrammer\azureus" and ".\azureus" to start it, where otherwise I would only have to use the command "azureus"...
drop a link to azureus in the ~/bin directory.
and add a launcher to the menu for ease
wait, what? How?
mkdir ~/bin && ln -s /path/to/azureus ~/bin/azureus
and that does make "azureus" a command?
yes. Any file (or link) in ~/bin is on the PATH, which is where bash looks for programs.  see     echo $PATH
should it point to the directory of azureus ("~\pogrammer\azureus") or the actual runfile thingie, (~\pogrammer\azureus\.azureus)?
the actual program
should it then be "~\pogrammer\azureus\azureus" or "~\pogrammer\azureus\.azureus"?
use the exact one that makes azureus run. Test thos on the command line, if necessary
or anyone, how can I run a program from a different folder? F.ex. if I'm in ~ and want to run ~\pogrammer\azureus\.azureus - what do I write?
you type that exact thing, but with forward slashes:  /
thanks, I got the slashes the wrong way.. d'oh
weird... writing "~/pogrammer/azureus/azureus" in terminal runs azureus, but the " mkdir ~/bin && ln -s ~/pogrammer/azureus/azureus ~/bin/azureus" didn't seem to have any effect at all...
you will have to log out and back in for ubuntu to recognize the ~/bin dir. Probably should have mentioned that :)
